questions.text: On which date did the World Health Organisation (WHO) officially declare that smallpox had been globally eradicated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The World Health Organisation (WHO) officially declared that smallpox had been globally eradicated on 8 May 1980.

  • The WHO officially declared smallpox eradicated on 8 May 1980, marking the end of a long and intensive global campaign to eliminate the disease.
  • This declaration followed years of coordinated efforts, including mass vaccination campaigns, surveillance, and containment measures, which successfully interrupted the global transmission of the smallpox virus.
  • This date marks a significant milestone in public health history, as smallpox became the first infectious disease to be eradicated through human efforts.
  • The last naturally occurring case of smallpox was reported in Somalia in 1977, but the official declaration of global eradication came later.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain. He has a history of frequently consuming street food. On examination, he is found to have jaundice and a tender hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show elevated transaminases. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's presentation is characteristic of acute viral hepatitis. His history of regularly consuming street food strongly suggests a faecal-oral route of transmission, which is typical of Hepatitis E virus (HEV).

  • Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is transmitted via the faecal-oral route, often through contaminated water or food.
  • It is particularly common in regions with poor sanitation and hygiene practices.
  • Acute hepatitis E typically presents with symptoms including nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fever, jaundice, and tender liver/hepatomegaly.
  • The human cases are the only reservoir of infection.
  • The risk of transmitting HAV is greatest from 2 weeks before to 1 week after the onset of jaundice. Infectivity falls rapidly with the onset of jaundice.
  • HAV is excreted in the faeces for about 2 weeks before the onset of jaundice and for up to 2 weeks thereafter.
  • Incubation period is 10 to 50 days (usually 14-28 days). The length of the incubation period is proportional to the dose of the virus ingested.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatitis B (Option A): Hepatitis B virus (HBV) can also cause acute hepatitis, but it is typically associated with parenteral transmissions such as unprotected sexual contact, exposure to infected blood or body fluids, or perinatal transmission.

Hepatitis C (Option C): Hepatitis C virus (HCV) primarily causes chronic hepatitis rather than acute hepatitis. Although acute infections can occur, it is less common and are often asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms. Additionally, Hepatitis C is typically transmitted through exposure to infected blood rather than through the ingestion of contaminated food or water.

Hepatitis D (Option D): Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is a defective virus that requires co-infection with Hepatitis B virus (HBV) for replication. It cannot cause infection independently and is seen only in individuals with HBV. Since there is no evidence of HBV infection in this case, HDV is an unlikely cause of the patient's acute hepatitis.

questions.text: All of the following can progress to chronic infection except-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hepatitis A is caused by the Hepatitis A virus (HAV) and is typically an acute, self-limiting infection.
  • It does not lead to chronic infection because the immune system usually clears the virus from the body within a few weeks to months after the initial infection.
  • Hepatitis A virus does not have a chronic carrier state, and individuals who recover from Hepatitis A develop immunity against future infections.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatitis B (Option B): Hepatitis B virus (HBV) can cause both acute and chronic infections. While most individuals clear the virus during the acute phase, a subset develops chronic hepatitis B, defined by persistence of HBsAg beyond six months. Chronic infection increases the risk of progressive liver disease, including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Hepatitis C (Option C): Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a leading cause of chronic liver disease. Unlike Hepatitis A, acute HCV infection progresses to chronicity in 75-85% of cases. Chronic HCV infection significantly increases the risk of cirrhosis, liver failure, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

Hepatitis D (Option D): Hepatitis D infection can occur as either a co-infection with HBV or as a superinfection in individuals already infected with HBV. Hepatitis D infection can progress to chronicity, especially in individuals with chronic Hepatitis B infection.

choices.text: Hepatitis A transmission risk is highest during the recovery phase of illness
Faecal shedding of the virus is at its highest during the later part of the incubation period
The incubation period of Hepatitis A ranges from 2 to 3 weeks
Hepatitis A commonly progresses to chronic liver disease in adults

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Hepatitis A is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hepatitis A is an acute infectious disease caused by the hepatitis A virus.
  • The disease is heralded by non-specific symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, fatigue, generalised weakness and aches and pains, followed by anorexia, nausea, vomiting, dark urine and jaundice.
  • The human cases are the only reservoir of infection.
  • Feco-oral route is the major route of transmission.

Period of infectivity:

  • HAV is excreted in the faeces for about 2 weeks before the onset of jaundice and for up to 2 weeks thereafter.
  • Faecal shedding of the virus is at its highest during the later part of the incubation period and early acute phase of illness. (Option A ruled out)
  • Thus, the risk of transmitting HAV is greatest from 2 weeks before to 1 week after the onset of jaundice.
  • Infectivity falls rapidly with the onset of jaundice.

Incubation period:

  • Incubation period is 10 to 50 days (usually 14-28 days). (Option C ruled out)
  • The length of the incubation period is proportional to the dose of the virus ingested

The disease is benign with complete recovery in several weeks. Hepatitis A resolves completely in 98 per cent of cases. The case fatality rate of icteric cases is less than 0.1 per cent, usually from acute liver failure and mainly affects older adults.(Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin only within 12 hours of birth
Administer hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin within 12 hours of birth
Administer hepatitis B vaccine only at 6 weeks of age
Administer immunoglobulin followed by vaccine after 1 month

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents in preterm labour at 34 weeks of gestation. She has not attended any antenatal visits during her pregnancy. On admission, she is found to be positive for HBsAg. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of the newborn immediately after birth to prevent vertical transmission?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In neonates born to HBsAg-positive mothers, the risk of vertical transmission of the Hepatitis B virus is significantly high.
  • To prevent perinatal transmission, the recommended protocol involves the administration of both Hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin within 12 hours of birth.
  • The hepatitis B vaccine provides active immunity by stimulating the neonate's immune response to develop protective antibodies.
  • Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin (HBIG) provides passive immunity through preformed anti-HBs antibodies, offering immediate protection.
  • This combination is significantly more effective than either intervention alone, reducing the risk of chronic HBV infection in exposed neonates by over 90%.

choices.text: Severe Rotavirus infections are primarily seen in children aged 5-7 years
The virus is shed in large quantities in the stool and vomitus of infected children for several days
Rotavirus infections peak during cooler and drier seasons
Improvements in water quality and hygiene have limited impact on reducing transmission

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Rotavirus infection is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rotavirus has emerged as the leading cause of severe, dehydrating diarrhoea in children aged <5 years globally.
  • In developing countries, three-quarters of children acquire their first episode of rotavirus diarrhoea before the age of 12 months, whereas in developed countries the first episode is frequently delayed until the age of 2-5 years.
  • Severe rotavirus gastroenteritis is largely limited to children aged 6-24 months.
  • Rotavirus reinfection is common, although the primary infection is usually the most significant clinically.
  • In temperate climates, the incidence of rotavirus gastroenteritis typically peaks during the winter season, whereas in tropical settings, rotavirus occurs year-round, and a marked seasonality may be masked by high background levels. (Option C ruled out)
  • Rotaviruses are shed in very high concentrations (>1012 particles/gram) and for many days in the stools and vomit of infected individuals. (Option C ruled out)
  • Transmission occurs primarily by the faecal-oral route, directly from person to person or indirectly via contaminated fomites.
  • The universal occurrence of rotavirus infections shows that clean water supplies and good hygiene are unlikely to have a substantial effect on virus transmission. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Rotarix is administered in 2 oral doses
Rotavirus vaccine should not be given to immunocompromised infants
The first dose of Rotarix is contraindicated for infants <12 weeks
It is not a part of catch-up vaccination programmes due to its risk of intussusception

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought in by the mother with complaints of diarrhoea and vomiting. As part of management, you counsel her about rotavirus vaccination. Which of the following statements regarding rotavirus vaccines is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The first dose of Rotarix can be given to infants as early as 6 weeks of age. There is no specific contraindication for the first dose of Rotarix in infants younger than 12 weeks, provided they are otherwise healthy and meet the age criteria for vaccination.

Rotavirus vaccine:

Two live, oral, attenuated rotavirus vaccines were licensed in 2006 :

  • Rotarix - The monovalent human rotavirus vaccine
  • Rota Teq - Pentavalent bovine-human, reassortant vaccine

Rotarix vaccine:

  • The Rotarix vaccine is administered orally in a 2-dose schedule to infants of approximately 2 and 4 months of age. (Option A ruled out)
  • The first dose can already be administered at the age of 6 weeks and should be given no later than the age of 12 weeks.
  • The 2nd dose should be completed by age 16 weeks and no later than 24 weeks of age.
  • The interval between the 2 doses should be at atleast 4 weeks.

RotaTeq vaccine:

  • For RotaTeq, the recommended schedule is three oral doses at ages 2, 4, and 6 months. The first dose should be administered between ages 6-12 weeks and subsequent doses at intervals of 4-10 weeks.
  • Vaccination should not be initiated for infants aged > 12 weeks.
  • All 3 doses should be administered before the age of 32 weeks.

Explanation of other options:

It cannot be given in an immunocompromised child (Option B): Rotavirus vaccines, such as Rotarix, are live attenuated formulations and are contraindicated in severely immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of unchecked replication of the vaccine strain and associated complications.

It is not a part of catchup vaccination programs due to its risk of intussusception (Option D): There is a potentially higher risk of intussusception when the first dose of these vaccines is given to infants aged > 12 weeks; consequently, current rotavirus vaccines should not be used in catch-up vaccination campaigns, where the exact age of the vaccinees may be difficult to ascertain.

questions.text: A convalescent carrier of cholera will remain infectious for how many days after recovery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Convalescent carriers of cholera can remain infectious and shed the bacteria for up to 14-21 days after recovery from the acute illness.
  • During this period, individuals may continue to excrete Vibrio cholerae in their stool, posing a risk of transmission to others if proper hygiene and sanitation measures are not followed.
  • Cholera is a bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, typically transmitted through contaminated food and water.
  • Individuals infected with cholera can shed the bacteria in their stool, potentially infecting others.
  • Even after recovering from the acute illness, some individuals can continue to shed the bacteria and remain carriers for a period of time.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the PHC with complaints of acute diarrhoea. On evaluating the history, the physician suspects Shigella infection rather than cholera. Which of the following features in the history, apart from the presence of bloody stools, supports the diagnosis of Shigella infection over cholera?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fever is a common symptom of shigellosis, whereas it is typically absent in uncomplicated cases of cholera. The presence of fever, especially in conjunction with bloody stools, is more indicative of a Shigella infection rather than cholera.

  • Shigella and cholera are both bacterial infections that can cause acute diarrhoea, but they have different clinical presentations and symptoms.
  • Shigella infection, also known as shigellosis, typically presents with symptoms such as bloody stools, fever, abdominal cramps, and sometimes vomiting.
  • Cholera, on the other hand, is characterised by profuse watery diarrhoea, vomiting, and dehydration, but it does not typically cause bloody stools unless there are severe complications.

Explanation of other options:

Absence of rectal pain (Option A): Rectal pain is not a specific symptom associated with either shigellosis or cholera. While patients with shigellosis may experience tenesmus (the feeling of incomplete bowel evacuation), which can cause discomfort or pain around the rectum, its absence does not strongly favour one diagnosis over the other.

Presence of abdominal cramps (Option B): Abdominal cramps are common symptoms in both shigellosis and cholera. Shigellosis often presents with severe abdominal cramps, but cholera can also cause abdominal discomfort due to the rapid onset of diarrhoea and dehydration.

Presence of vomiting (Option C): Vomiting is also a symptom that can occur in both shigellosis and cholera, although it is more commonly associated with cholera. Cholera-induced vomiting can occur due to the body's attempt to expel the toxins produced by the bacteria.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male is diagnosed with cholera. To prevent secondary cases among close household contacts, which of the following is recommended as chemoprophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tetracycline is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis in Cholera.
  • Tetracycline works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis, thereby stopping the growth and multiplication of the bacteria.
  • Alternatively, the long-acting tetracycline-doxycycline may be used for chemoprophylaxis if the prevailing strains are not resistant.
  • Chemoprophylaxis for cholera is recommended only for household contacts or closed community contacts, as mass chemoprophylaxis is ineffective and offers only short-term protection.

Explanation of other options:

Azithromycin (Option B), Ciprofloxacin (Option C): Both are effective for treating cholera but are not recommended for prophylaxis; it is reserved for managing active cases rather than preventing infection in contacts.

Cotrimoxazole (Option D): Cotrimoxazole is not routinely used in cholera due to resistance, but may be considered in select cases based on local sensitivity. It is more commonly used in infections like urinary tract infections, Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, and certain diarrheal diseases like shigellosis.

Key Takeaway:

Drug of choice for cholera chemoprophylaxis: Tetracycline

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective prophylactic measure against cholera?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Health education plays a pivotal role in the prevention of cholera by promoting key hygiene and sanitation practices.
  • It involves creating awareness among individuals and communities about safe drinking water, proper food handling, hand hygiene, environmental sanitation and also the effectiveness and simplicity of oral rehydration therapy.
  • Emphasising practices such as hand washing after defecation and before eating, consumption of treated water, and the safe disposal of human waste helps reduce the risk of faecal-oral transmission.
  • By addressing the underlying causes of cholera spread, health education serves as the most effective and sustainable prophylactic measure against the disease.
  • While vaccination, chemoprophylaxis, and early case detection are important components of cholera control and prevention efforts, they are not as comprehensive or universally applicable as health education in reducing the burden of cholera.

Explanation of other options:

Vaccination (Option B): Cholera vaccination offers individual protection, particularly in endemic areas, during outbreaks, or for travellers. However, its effectiveness as a prophylactic measure is limited by factors such as vaccine availability, coverage, and circulating strains. Importantly, vaccination does not address the root causes of transmission, such as poor sanitation and hygiene.

Chemoprophylaxis (Option C): Chemoprophylaxis uses antibiotics to prevent cholera in high-risk individuals, such as household contacts or outbreak responders. Though it may help limit transmission in specific situations, it is not widely recommended due to concerns like antibiotic resistance, side effects, and the need for repeated dosing.

Early case detection (Option D): Early case detection aids in prompt treatment and limits transmission through case management and contact tracing. However, it is not a true prophylactic measure, as it does not address the root causes of cholera or prevent new infections on its own.

choices.text: Ensure a safe water supply and improve sanitation
Vaccinate all the unaffected individuals against cholera
Conduct epidemiological investigations to identify the source and transmission

questions.text: You are a medical officer posted in a village experiencing a cholera outbreak. To reduce the incidence of the disease effectively, what should be your first intervention?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The first step that should be taken to decrease the incidence of cholera in a village affected by an epidemic is ensuring a safe water supply and improving sanitation.

  • Improving the safety of water sources and ensuring proper sanitation facilities are crucial steps in preventing and controlling cholera outbreaks, as water is the most important vehicle of transmission of cholera.
  • Providing access to safe drinking water through sources such as piped water systems, protected wells, or water purification methods can help reduce the risk of contamination with Vibrio cholerae.
  • The provision of a piped water supply and the elimination of alternative, unsafe water sources are the ultimate aim in most regions.
  • Additionally, promoting proper sanitation practices, such as the construction and use of latrines or toilets and the safe disposal of human waste, can prevent faecal-oral transmission of the bacteria and interrupt the cycle of infection.
  • Safe water supply and sanitation measures address the underlying factors contributing to cholera transmission and help prevent future outbreaks.
  • Since food may be an important vehicle of infection, steps should be taken to improve food sanitation, particularly the sale of foods under hygienic conditions.
  • Health education must stress the importance of eating cooked hot food and of proper individual food handling techniques.
  • Cooking utensils should be cleaned and dried after use.

Explanation of other options:

Vaccinate all the unaffected individuals against cholera (Option B): Cholera vaccination offers protection, especially in endemic areas and high-risk groups, but mass vaccination is often impractical during outbreaks. Vaccination alone does not address the underlying causes of transmission, making it less effective as an immediate control measure.

Mass chemoprophylaxis (Option C): Mass chemoprophylaxis is not recommended for entire communities because preventing one serious cholera case would require treating about 10,000 people, and the drug's protective effect lasts only a few days. Therefore, chemoprophylaxis is advised only for household contacts or members of a closed community where cholera cases have occurred. Tetracycline is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis.

Conduct epidemiological investigations to identify the source and transmission (Option D): Conducting epidemiological studies is important for identifying the outbreak source, but not the immediate and most effective step to reduce cases. The priority is to implement sanitation measures safe water, hygiene, and sanitation measures to quickly stop transmission. Epidemiological investigations should run concurrently to guide further control.

Key Takeaways:

  • Health education is the most effective cholera prophylaxis.
  • Tetracycline is the drug of choice for cholera chemoprophylaxis.
  • Mass chemoprophylaxis is limited to household contacts and closed communities.
  • The first step in a cholera outbreak is to ensure safe water and sanitation.

questions.text: A cholera patient soils the bed with stool in the ward. Which chemical is most appropriate for disinfecting the bed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cresol-based disinfectants are commonly used for cleaning and disinfecting surfaces contaminated with organic matter, such as faecal material.

Disinfection in Cholera control:

  • Disinfection should be both concurrent and terminal.
  • The most effective disinfectant for general use is a coal tar disinfectant with a Rideal-Walker (RW) coefficient of 10 or more, such as cresol.
  • Cresol, also known as cresylic acid, is a disinfectant and antiseptic agent that is effective against a wide range of microorganisms, including bacteria and fungi.
  • A disinfectant with an RW coefficient of less than 5 should not be used.
  • For disinfection, attention should be paid to the following: the patient's stools and vomit; clothes and other personal items that may have been contaminated; the latrine, if any; the patient's house and neighbourhood.

Explanation of other options:

Bleaching powder ( Option A), Chlorine (Option D): Bleaching powder, also known as calcium hypochlorite, is widely used as a disinfectant due to its ability to release chlorine when dissolved in water. They are widely used for water treatment and surface disinfection. Though effective against Vibrio cholerae due to their strong antimicrobial action, they lack sufficient cleaning and deodorising properties for surfaces heavily soiled with cholera stools. If bleaching powder is used, it must be of good quality to ensure effective disinfection.

Hydrogen peroxide (Option C): Hydrogen peroxide is a strong oxidising agent that is commonly used as a disinfectant and antiseptic. While hydrogen peroxide can effectively kill bacteria, viruses, and fungi, it does not provide sufficient cleaning and decontamination of surfaces, particularly in cases of heavy soiling.

choices.text: Cholera must be reported to the WHO by the national authority within 72 hours of detection
Cases and deaths should be reported daily and weekly until the area is declared cholera-free
An area is declared cholera-free after one month without a reported case
Mass chemoprophylaxis must be initiated immediately in the affected area

questions.text: Cholera is a notifiable disease at both national and international levels. According to the International Health Regulations (IHR), which of the following statements is correct regarding its notification?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As a part of surveillance during a cholera outbreak, it is mandatory to that the number of cases and deaths is also to be reported daily and weekly till the area is declared free of cholera.

  • Cholera is a notifiable disease locally and nationally. Since 2005, notification is no longer mandatory internationally. (Option A ruled out)
  • Health workers at all levels, particularly those who are closest to the community, such as the community health workers and the multi-purpose workers, should be trained to identify and notify cases immediately to the local health authority.
  • Under the International Health Regulations, cholera is notifiable to the WHO within 24 hours of its occurrence by the National Government.
  • The number of cases and deaths is also to be reported daily and weekly till the area is declared free of cholera. It helps monitor the progression of outbreaks, assess the effectiveness of control measures, and determine when it is appropriate to declare the end of an outbreak.
  • An area is declared free of cholera when twice the incubation period (i.e., 10 days) has elapsed since the death, recovery or isolation of the last case. (Option C ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Mass chemoprophylaxis must be initiated immediately in the affected area
(Option D): Mass chemoprophylaxis and the widespread use of antibiotics to prevent cholera are not routinely recommended under the International Health Regulations (IHR). Its use depends on specific outbreak conditions such as severity, risk of spread, and available resources. While it may be considered in select situations, it is not a standard or mandatory measure and should be carefully evaluated based on the local epidemiological context and public health priorities.

choices.text: Intravenous fluids initially for 4 hours, followed by oral fluids

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with 15 episodes of loose stools in the last 24 hours and 2 episodes of vomiting in the past 4 hours. He is restless, has sunken eyes, and appears irritable, but can drink fluids. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child's signs and symptoms, such as restlessness, sunken eyes, irritability, and the ability to drink, suggest mild dehydration due to acute gastroenteritis. In such cases, Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT) is the treatment of choice.

Appropriate clinical management of diarrhoea:

Oral rehydration therapy:

  • ORT involves giving Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS), which contains the right balance of glucose and electrolytes to restore fluid and electrolyte losses.
  • It is based on the fact that glucose promotes sodium and water absorption in the gut, making ORT effective.
  • ORS should be given in small, frequent sips to ensure proper hydration and tolerance.

Intravenous fluids:

  • Intravenous infusion is usually required only for the initial rehydration of severely dehydrated patients who are in shock or unable to drink. (Option A, C ruled out)
  • The solutions recommended by WHO for intravenous infusion are:
    • Ringer's lactate
    • Diarrhoea Treatment Solution (DTS)

Maintenance therapy:

  • After the initial fluid and electrolyte deficit has been corrected (i.e., the signs of dehydration), oral fluid should be used for maintenance therapy.

Chemotherapy:

  • Unnecessary prescription of antibiotics and other drugs will do more harm than good in the treatment of diarrhoea. (Option D ruled out)
  • Antibiotics should be considered where the cause of diarrhoea has been identified as Shigella, typhoid or cholera.

Zinc supplementation:

  • When a zinc supplement is given during an episode of acute diarrhoea, it reduces the duration and severity.
  • In addition, zinc supplements given for 10 to 14 days lower the incidence of diarrhoea in the following 2 to 3 months.
  • WHO and UNICEF therefore recommend daily 10 mg of zinc for infants under 6 months of age, and 20 mg for children older than 6 months for 10-14 days

choices.text: Give 200-400 ml of ORS in the first 4 hours
Give 400-700 ml of ORS in the first 4 hours
Give 700-900 ml of ORS in the first 4 hours
In addition to usual fluids, give 100-200 ml of ORS after each loose stool

questions.text: A 9 kg infant with diarrhoea is feeding well and thirsty. The skin pinch returns slowly, taking about 4 seconds. What is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child's ability to feed and evident thirst suggest some dehydration, while a skin pinch returning in 4 seconds indicates moderate fluid loss.
  • According to WHO guidelines, children with some dehydration require 75-100 mL/kg of ORS over 4 hours. For a 9 kg infant, this equals 675-900 mL.
  • However, since the child is alert, feeding well, and showing early signs, a dose on the lower end, approximately 400-700 mL over 4 hours, is appropriate and effective.

Oral rehydration therapy for dehydration:

  • Oral fluid therapy aims to prevent dehydration and reduce mortality.
  • Oral fluid therapy is based on the observation that glucose given orally enhances the intestinal absorption of salt and water and is capable of correcting the electrolyte and water deficit.
  • ORS solutions are safe and effective in preventing and treating diarrhoeal dehydration.
  • When obvious signs of dehydration exist, the water deficit is somewhere between 50 and 100 ml per kg of body weight.
  • If the child's weight is known, the amount of ORS solution required for rehydration during the first four hours may be calculated by setting the deficit at approximately 75 ml/kg.
  • If the child's weight is not known, the approximate deficit may be determined on the basis of age.

Key Takeaways:

In the management of dehydration in children with diarrhoea, the recommended rehydration volume over the first 4 hours is 75 mL/kg.

choices.text: A solution made with 1 teaspoon of salt and 6 teaspoons of sugar in 1 litre of clean water
Unsalted water in which a cereal has been cooked
Soup with 3 g/l salt added to it

questions.text: Which of the following home fluids is not recommended for managing a child with diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • While unsalted cereal water may appear harmless, it lacks the essential sodium and glucose needed for proper rehydration.
  • Effective rehydration in diarrhoea requires fluids that help restore electrolyte balance, which plain or unsalted fluids cannot provide.
  • Using such fluids may even worsen dehydration by further diluting the body's electrolyte levels, making them unsuitable as home remedies for managing diarrhoea in children.
  • Oral rehydration therapy is the cornerstone of diarrheal disease management, crucial for preventing dehydration and reducing mortality.
  • The WHO-recommended reduced osmolarity ORS solutions are the most effective for this purpose.
  • If the WHO mixture of salts is not available, a simple mixture consisting of table salt (one level teaspoon) and sugar (6 level teaspoons) dissolved in one litre of drinking water may be safely used until the proper mixture is obtained. (Option A ruled out)
  • Many countries have designated recommended household fluids. Wherever possible, these should include at least one fluid that contains salt.
  • Fluids that do not contain salt are water in which a cereal has been cooked, e.g. rice water; unsalted soup, yoghurt drinks, green coconut water, weak tea, etc.
  • The mothers should be taught to add about 3 g/litre salt to an unsalted drink or soup during diarrhoea. (Option C, D ruled out)
  • A few fluids are potentially dangerous and should be avoided during diarrhoea. Especially important are drinks sweetened with sugar, which can cause osmotic diarrhoea and hypernatremia. Examples are commercial beverages, commercial fruit juices and sweetened tea.
  • Other fluids to be avoided are those with stimulant, diuretic or purgative effect, e.g. coffee and some medicinal tea or infusions.

questions.text: A child with severe dehydration has been receiving intravenous fluids for 2 hours. Which of the following is the best early indicator of adequate rehydration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Skin turgor, or elasticity, is a reliable clinical sign for assessing hydration in both children and adults.
  • When adequately hydrated, the skin quickly snaps back to its normal position after being pinched.
  • In dehydration, skin recoil is delayed, showing poor turgor.
  • Therefore, improvement in skin turgor, demonstrated by faster skin return after a pinch, indicates effective rehydration and fluid balance restoration.
  • It serves as an early indicator of adequate rehydration in children treated with intravenous fluids.
  • While the presence of tears, urine flow rate, and moistness of the tongue can also reflect hydration status, they are less reliable early indicators because they may take longer to change, can be influenced by other factors, or require extended observation. (Option B, C, D ruled out)

choices.text: 20 mg zinc daily for infants under 12 months of age for 10-14 days
20 mg zinc daily for children over 6 months of age for 7 days
10 mg zinc daily for children over 12 months of age for 20 days
10 mg zinc daily for children under 6 months of age for 10-14 days

questions.text: What is the recommended dosage for zinc supplements in children with diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Zinc supplementation is an important adjunct therapy for the management of diarrhoea in children, as it helps reduce the duration and severity of diarrheal episodes and promotes recovery.
  • The recommended dosage of zinc supplements varies depending on the age of the child.
  • Recommended dose of zinc for children:
    • < 6 months of age: 10 mg daily for 10 to 14 days.
    • > 6 months of age: 20 mg daily for 10-14 days.

questions.text: What is the recommended sodium concentration in the rehydration fluid for a child with Severe Acute Malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A sodium concentration of 45 mmol/l is within the recommended range for rehydration fluids in children with SAM, helping to prevent hyponatremia while avoiding the risk of hypernatremia associated with higher sodium concentrations.

  • Children with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) are highly vulnerable to complications such as electrolyte imbalances, particularly hyponatremia.
  • ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition) is the recommended fluid for rehydration in SAM because it contains lower sodium, higher potassium and glucose, and has a lower osmolarity compared to standard WHO ORS.
  • This formulation helps correct imbalances without risking fluid overload.
  • In SAM children with bilateral pitting oedema, elevated intracellular sodium levels increase the risk of fluid retention and heart failure.
  • A sodium concentration of 45 mmol/L is appropriate for rehydration in children with SAM, minimising the risk of both hyponatremia and hypernatremia.

choices.text: The incubation period of typhoid is typically 3-5 days
Chronic carriers excrete S. typhi for more than one year
Humans, especially chronic carriers, serve as the primary reservoir for S. typhi
Tetracycline is the preferred treatment for carriers

questions.text: An outbreak of typhoid fever has been reported in a boy's hostel, and the hostel cook has been identified as a carrier of Salmonella typhi. Which of the following statements about typhoid fever is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A person who continues to shed Salmonella typhi for ≥12 months after acute infection qualifies as a chronic carrier.

  • typhi is the major cause of enteric fever.
  • Man is the only known reservoir of infection, viz., cases and carriers. (Option C ruled out)
  • A case or carrier is infectious as long as bacilli appear in the stools or urine.

Typhoid carriers:

  • The carriers may be temporary (incubatory, convalescent) or chronic.
  • Convalescent carriers excrete the bacilli for 6 to 8 weeks, after which their numbers diminish rapidly.
  • Persons who excrete the bacilli for more than a year after a clinical attack are called chronic carriers.
  • In most chronic carriers, the organisms persist in the gall bladder and in the biliary tract.
  • A chronic carrier may excrete the bacilli for several years (may be as long as 50 years) either continuously or intermittently.

Source of infection:

  • The primary sources of infection are faeces and urine of cases or carriers; the secondary sources are contaminated water, food, fingers and flies.

Mode of transmission:

  • Typhoid fever is transmitted via the faeco-oral route or the urine-oral route.

Incubation Period:

  • The incubation period is usually 10-14 days. But it may be as short as 3 days or as long as three weeks, depending upon the dose of the bacilli ingested. (Option A ruled out)

Treatment:

  • The fluoroquinolones are widely regarded as the drug of choice for the treatment of typhoid fever.
  • The optimum treatment for quinolone-resistant typhoid fever is azithromycin or the third-generation cephalosporins, or a 10-14-day course of high-dose fluoroquinolones.
  • The recommended treatments for chronic carriers include an intensive course of ampicillin or amoxycillin (4-6 g a day) together with Probenecid (2 g/day) for 6 weeks.
  • Cholecystectomy with concomitant ampicillin therapy has been regarded as the most successful approach to the treatment of carriers.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not communicable during the later part of its incubation period?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Typhoid fever, caused by Salmonella typhi, is not communicable during the later part of its incubation period.
  • The incubation period typically ranges from 7 to 14 days, during which the infected individual may begin to show early symptoms such as fever, malaise, and abdominal discomfort.
  • However, during this stage, the bacteria are not shed in significant quantities, so the risk of transmission is very low.
  • Transmission primarily occurs during the acute phase, when the bacteria are actively shed in the stool and can contaminate food or water.
  • Humans, especially chronic carriers, are the only known reservoir of the disease.
  • Infectious diseases like measles, whooping cough, and diphtheria can be communicable during the later stages of their incubation periods, meaning individuals can spread the infection before showing symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases can be transmitted during the incubatory carrier state?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Incubatory carriers are those who shed the infectious agent during the incubation period of the disease.
  • Thus, they are capable of infecting others before the onset of illness.
  • This usually occurs during the last few days of the incubation period,
  • Some diseases with incubatory carriers:
    • Measles
    • Mumps
    • Polio
    • Pertussis
    • Influenza
    • Diphtheria
    • Hepatitis A

questions.text: Which of the following diseases doesn't have healthy carriers?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Individuals with typhoid fever shed Salmonella Typhi in their faeces mainly during the acute phase of illness.
  • While most patients stop shedding bacteria after recovery, some become convalescent carriers, continuing to excrete the bacteria during the convalescence period.
  • The primary transmission of typhoid is through ingestion of contaminated food or water rather than from healthy carriers.
  • Thus, typhoid involves convalescent carriers and does not have healthy carriers.

Healthy carriers:

  • Healthy carriers emerge from subclinical cases.
  • They are victims of subclinical infection who have developed a carrier state without suffering from overt disease.
  • Thus, healthy carriers are individuals who harbour and shed infectious agents without displaying symptoms of the disease themselves.
  • Disease with a healthy carrier state:
    • Poliomyelitis
    • Cholera
    • Meningococcal meningitis
    • Salmonellosis
    • Diphtheria

Safe disposal of human waste, safe water supply, and personal hygiene are more important than immunisation
Drug resistance in typhoid is less significant compared to tuberculosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about typhoid control measures is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Typhoid fever is primarily spread through the feco-oral route, often due to contaminated water or food.
  • Therefore, measures aimed at improving sanitation, providing clean water, and promoting good hygiene practices, such as handwashing, are fundamental in preventing the transmission of the disease.
  • These measures address the root causes of typhoid transmission and can significantly reduce the incidence of the disease, especially in endemic areas.

Explanation of other options:

Immunisation is the most important control measure (Option A): While typhoid control relies primarily on improved sanitation, safe water, and personal hygiene, these are long-term solutions. Immunisation serves as an important complementary measure that reduces disease incidence and severity but does not offer complete protection. Combining both approaches is essential for effective typhoid prevention.

Drug resistance in typhoid is less significant compared to tuberculosis (Option C): Drug-resistant strains of Salmonella Typhi have become an increasing public health concern, particularly in endemic regions. The rise of multidrug-resistant strains complicates the treatment of typhoid fever and undermines control efforts, especially in areas with limited access to effective antibiotics.

Person-to-person transmission occurs in 10% of cases (Option D): Typhoid fever mainly spreads via faecal-oral or urine-oral routes. Thus, transmission typically occurs indirectly through ingestion of food or water contaminated by faeces or urine of infected individuals or carriers. Direct person-to-person transmission via contaminated hands is possible but relatively rare.

questions.text: The Levine criteria have been proposed for the diagnosis of which among the following neurological conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Levine criteria were proposed as a structured set of neurological findings to support the clinical diagnosis of Cerebral Palsy.

  • These criteria are based on six observable neurological signs, remembered by the mnemonic POSTER:
    • P:Posturing
    • O: Oropharyngeal problems
    • S: Strabismus
    • T: Tone abnormalities
    • E: Evolutional maldevelopment, e.g. Persistent primitive reflexes
    • R: Reflexes are increased or brisk, or exaggerated, e.g. DTRs
  • The presence of any 4 out of 6 strongly suggests the diagnosis of cerebral palsy.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7416928/
